channel.title: Global News Podcast
channel.description: The latest from Israel and Gaza and all the top stories from BBC News. Twice a day on weekdays, daily at weekends and special episodes. Reports and analysis from around the world.
channel.itunes:summary: The latest from Israel and Gaza and all the top stories from BBC News. Twice a day on weekdays, daily at weekends and special episodes. Reports and analysis from around the world.
channel.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Yemen strikes: Houthis hit US-owned ship after 'terror' designation
item.description: Houthis target vessel after US re-designates the group as "global terrorists". Also: British PM secures crucial parliamentary vote on plans to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda, and Irish language rappers heading stateside for Sundance.
item.itunes:subtitle: Houthis target vessel after Washington re-designates the group as "global terrorists"
item.itunes:summary: Houthis target vessel after US re-designates the group as "global terrorists". Also: British PM secures crucial parliamentary vote on plans to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda, and Irish language rappers heading stateside for Sundance.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: China's population drops for a second straight year
item.description: China, which once tried to control population growth with a one-child policy, is concerned the decline could seriously harm the world’s second largest economy. Also: Crowds clash with riot police in Russia over a jailed activist, and the drug offering a less invasive treatment for children with blood cancer.
item.itunes:subtitle: The fall is due to a record low birth rate and deaths linked to Covid-19
item.itunes:summary: China, which once tried to control population growth with a one-child policy, is concerned the decline could seriously harm the world’s second largest economy. Also: Crowds clash with riot police in Russia over a jailed activist, and the drug offering a less invasive treatment for children with blood cancer.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US calls for a 'de-escalation' in tensions in the Middle East
item.description: The US National Security Advisor, Jake Sullivan, says the course of the Mideast conflict depends on Iran. Also: Pakistan condemns Iran for carrying out a deadly missile strike on Baluchistan, and Chinese scientists clone monkey to speed up medical research.
item.itunes:subtitle: Washington says it has seized Iranian weaponry from a dhow heading to Yemen
item.itunes:summary: The US National Security Advisor, Jake Sullivan, says the course of the Mideast conflict depends on Iran. Also: Pakistan condemns Iran for carrying out a deadly missile strike on Baluchistan, and Chinese scientists clone monkey to speed up medical research.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Donald Trump wins Iowa caucuses
item.description: Mr Trump scores an overwhelming victory over his rivals in this first step towards deciding the Republican party's candidate for president. Iran launches deadly missile strikes into Kurdistan, claiming to target an Israeli spy headquarters. And the TV drama Succession wins big at the Emmy awards.
item.itunes:subtitle: The former president scores an overwhelming victory over his Republican rivals
item.itunes:summary: Mr Trump scores an overwhelming victory over his rivals in this first step towards deciding the Republican party's candidate for president. Iran launches deadly missile strikes into Kurdistan, claiming to target an Israeli spy headquarters. And the TV drama Succession wins big at the Emmy awards.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US cargo ship hit by Houthi missile
item.description: The Houthis say all US and British ships taking part in what they call the aggression against Yemen would be targets. Also: Hamas releases a video purportedly confirming the deaths of two more Israeli hostages, and a new culturally sensitive version of the Prince of Persia video game is released.
item.itunes:subtitle: The vessel reported no injuries or serious damage and is continuing its journey
item.itunes:summary: The Houthis say all US and British ships taking part in what they call the aggression against Yemen would be targets. Also: Hamas releases a video purportedly confirming the deaths of two more Israeli hostages, and a new culturally sensitive version of the Prince of Persia video game is released.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine says it shot down Russian spy plane
item.description: Analysts say it would be a "major blow to Moscow's air power", if confirmed. Also: Bernardo Arevalo is finally sworn in as Guatemala's new president after hours of delays, and the singer Zayn Malik, formerly of One Direction, releases a song in Urdu.
item.itunes:subtitle: Analysts say it would be a "major blow to Moscow's air power"
item.itunes:summary: Analysts say it would be a "major blow to Moscow's air power", if confirmed. Also: Bernardo Arevalo is finally sworn in as Guatemala's new president after hours of delays, and the singer Zayn Malik, formerly of One Direction, releases a song in Urdu.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Denmark proclaims a new King
item.description: In an historic moment, tens of thousands watch Frederik X blink back tears as he takes the throne from his mother who ruled for 52 years. Also: The security forces in Ecuador launch an operation to regain control of prisons taken over by violent drug gangs, and Lava from a volcanic eruption in Iceland reaches the town of Grindavik, setting some houses on fire.
item.itunes:subtitle: Frederik X succeeds his mother Margrethe who abdicated for health reasons
item.itunes:summary: In an historic moment, tens of thousands watch Frederik X blink back tears as he takes the throne from his mother who ruled for 52 years. Also: The security forces in Ecuador launch an operation to regain control of prisons taken over by violent drug gangs, and Lava from a volcanic eruption in Iceland reaches the town of Grindavik, setting some houses on fire.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Pro-sovereignty leader wins Taiwan's election
item.description: William Lai, the man described as 'a troublemaker' by China, will lead the Democratic Progressive Party for a third consecutive term. Also: President Biden says he has sent a private message to Iran about the Houthis in Yemen following US airstrikes against the group and, can real translators be replaced by Artificial Intelligence?
item.itunes:subtitle: Beijing issues a statement warning that the territory is 'part of China'
item.itunes:summary: William Lai, the man described as 'a troublemaker' by China, will lead the Democratic Progressive Party for a third consecutive term. Also: President Biden says he has sent a private message to Iran about the Houthis in Yemen following US airstrikes against the group and, can real translators be replaced by Artificial Intelligence?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: The Happy Pod: Trapped tourists saved from flooded caves
item.description: Five people were rescued from a system of underground lakes in southern Slovenia. Also: scientists say they've decoded a baby's cry. And, the mouse that's been caught tidying up a garden shed.
item.itunes:subtitle: The happiest stories in the world - our weekly collection
item.itunes:summary: Five people were rescued from a system of underground lakes in southern Slovenia. Also: scientists say they've decoded a baby's cry. And, the mouse that's been caught tidying up a garden shed.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Biden: US will respond if Houthis continue 'outrageous behaviour'
item.description: Washington says the Houthi armed group in Yemen has fired a missile at a ship in the Gulf of Aden in apparent retaliation for Western airstrikes. Also: Israel says Qatar has helped broker a deal that would see medicines reach hostages held by Hamas in exchange for Israel letting more aid into Gaza, and the World Health Organisation declares Cape Verde free of malaria, calling it a significant milestone in the fight against the disease.
item.itunes:subtitle: Iranian-backed Houthis follow through on pledge to continue targeting ships
item.itunes:summary: Washington says the Houthi armed group in Yemen has fired a missile at a ship in the Gulf of Aden in apparent retaliation for Western airstrikes. Also: Israel says Qatar has helped broker a deal that would see medicines reach hostages held by Hamas in exchange for Israel letting more aid into Gaza, and the World Health Organisation declares Cape Verde free of malaria, calling it a significant milestone in the fight against the disease.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Houthis vow retaliation for Western strikes in Yemen
item.description: It comes after the US and Britain hit 16 strategic Houthi positions overnight. Also: Israel rebuffs South Africa's accusations of genocide at the UN's top court, a huge ring of galaxies challenges thinking on cosmos and can passkeys replace passwords?
item.itunes:subtitle: It comes after the US and Britain hit 16 strategic Houthi positions overnight
item.itunes:summary: It comes after the US and Britain hit 16 strategic Houthi positions overnight. Also: Israel rebuffs South Africa's accusations of genocide at the UN's top court, a huge ring of galaxies challenges thinking on cosmos and can passkeys replace passwords?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US and UK launch strikes against Houthi rebels in Yemen
item.description: President Biden says strikes targeted military facilities to protect global shipping from attacks. Also: Trump blasts New York judge as fraud trial ends, and a huge ancient city is found in the Amazon.
item.itunes:subtitle: President Biden says strikes protected global shipping from attacks
item.itunes:summary: President Biden says strikes targeted military facilities to protect global shipping from attacks. Also: Trump blasts New York judge as fraud trial ends, and a huge ancient city is found in the Amazon.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US and UK finalise strike plans against Houthi rebel targets in Yemen
item.description: In preparation for strike action on the Iranian-backed Houthis, the UK government and the Pentagon held briefings on Thursday evening. Also: Trump blasts New York judge as fraud trial ends, and a huge ancient city is found in the Amazon.
item.itunes:subtitle: Houthis have repeatedly carried out attacks on commercial vessels in the Red Sea
item.itunes:summary: In preparation for strike action on the Iranian-backed Houthis, the UK government and the Pentagon held briefings on Thursday evening. Also: Trump blasts New York judge as fraud trial ends, and a huge ancient city is found in the Amazon.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Judges told that top Israeli officials want Gaza destroyed
item.description: International Court of Justice hears genocide claim lodged by South Africa. Israel dismisses the case as baseless. Also: China warns voters in Taiwan -- two days before they go to the polls to elect a new president. And Bitcoin goes mainstream in the US: will that help end the wild volatility of cryptocurrencies?
item.itunes:subtitle: International Court of Justice hears claim lodged by South Africa
item.itunes:summary: International Court of Justice hears genocide claim lodged by South Africa. Israel dismisses the case as baseless. Also: China warns voters in Taiwan -- two days before they go to the polls to elect a new president. And Bitcoin goes mainstream in the US: will that help end the wild volatility of cryptocurrencies?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: UK to bring in law to quash wrongful Post Office convictions
item.description: Between 1999 and 2015 hundreds of local post office managers in UK were convicted of theft and fraud over money that only appeared to be missing because of faults in a new IT system. Also: Ecuador's president declares war on armed gangs after days of violence, and ancient DNA sheds new light on how multiple sclerosis developed.
item.itunes:subtitle: The legal step followed public outrage after a TV drama was aired
item.itunes:summary: Between 1999 and 2015 hundreds of local post office managers in UK were convicted of theft and fraud over money that only appeared to be missing because of faults in a new IT system. Also: Ecuador's president declares war on armed gangs after days of violence, and ancient DNA sheds new light on how multiple sclerosis developed.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: "Neutralise" armed groups - Ecuador president
item.description: President Noboa gave the go-ahead to the military after drug gangs took over a TV station. Also: protests and strikes cause havoc for commuters in Germany, and bribery and match fixing in Chinese football.
item.itunes:subtitle: President Noboa gave the go-ahead to the military after drug gangs stormed a TV station
item.itunes:summary: President Noboa gave the go-ahead to the military after drug gangs took over a TV station. Also: protests and strikes cause havoc for commuters in Germany, and bribery and match fixing in Chinese football.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Gunmen storm Ecuador TV studio during broadcast
item.description: Footage shows armed men wearing masks surrounding journalists in the Guayaquil-based newsroom. Also: US judges sound sceptical of Trump's immunity defence, and one of the biggest names in Indian classical music, Rashid Khan, dies aged 55.
item.itunes:subtitle: Staff were forced to lie on the floor as the live feed was cut
item.itunes:summary: Footage shows armed men wearing masks surrounding journalists in the Guayaquil-based newsroom. Also: US judges sound sceptical of Trump's immunity defence, and one of the biggest names in Indian classical music, Rashid Khan, dies aged 55.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: 2023 was officially the hottest year on record
item.description: Last year was officially the warmest ever recorded, according to the European climate monitoring organisation, Copernicus. Also: the US continues its diplomatic efforts in Israel as 57 deaths are reported in one central Gaza hospital overnight, and South Korea bans the killing and selling of dogs for food.
item.itunes:subtitle: Last year was the hottest on record, with this year tipped to be even hotter
item.itunes:summary: Last year was officially the warmest ever recorded, according to the European climate monitoring organisation, Copernicus. Also: the US continues its diplomatic efforts in Israel as 57 deaths are reported in one central Gaza hospital overnight, and South Korea bans the killing and selling of dogs for food.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Blinken arrives in Israel amid fears the Gaza conflict could escalate in the region
item.description: The US Secretary of State, Antony Blinken, is expected to reiterate calls to Israel to do more to reduce civilian deaths in Gaza. Also: one of the legends of international football, Franz Beckenbauer, has died aged 78, and the scientists who say they had a "conversation" with a humpback whale!
item.itunes:subtitle: Reports from Gaza say nearly 250 people were killed in the last 24 hours
item.itunes:summary: The US Secretary of State, Antony Blinken, is expected to reiterate calls to Israel to do more to reduce civilian deaths in Gaza. Also: one of the legends of international football, Franz Beckenbauer, has died aged 78, and the scientists who say they had a "conversation" with a humpback whale!
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Hezbollah says a senior commander has been killed by Israel in Lebanon
item.description: Wissam-al-Tawil was the deputy head of the militant group’s elite Radwan force. It comes on the day the US Secretary of State is due in Tel Aviv. Also: A US moon mission takes off for the first time in more than 50 years, and Oppenheimer and Succession sweep the Golden Globe Awards.
item.itunes:subtitle: Wissam-al-Tawil was the deputy head of the militant group’s elite Radwan force
item.itunes:summary: Wissam-al-Tawil was the deputy head of the militant group’s elite Radwan force. It comes on the day the US Secretary of State is due in Tel Aviv. Also: A US moon mission takes off for the first time in more than 50 years, and Oppenheimer and Succession sweep the Golden Globe Awards.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Dozens killed in Israeli strike on Jabalia
item.description: Witnesses say the IDF hit homes in a densely populated refugee camp in northern Gaza. Also: Sheikh Hasina wins a fifth term as prime minister of Bangladesh, in an election boycotted by the opposition. And, the first Afghan woman to fly a passenger jet tells us about her experience as a refugee.
item.itunes:subtitle: Witnesses say the IDF hit houses in refugee camp
item.itunes:summary: Witnesses say the IDF hit homes in a densely populated refugee camp in northern Gaza. Also: Sheikh Hasina wins a fifth term as prime minister of Bangladesh, in an election boycotted by the opposition. And, the first Afghan woman to fly a passenger jet tells us about her experience as a refugee.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US grounds Boeing 737 planes after mid-air emergency
item.description: The Federal Aviation Authority says Boeing 737 Max 9 jets must be inspected before flying again, after part of a plane's fuselage blew off during a US flight. The same Boeing models were grounded after deadly crashes in Ethiopia and Indonesia five years ago. Also: The Israeli army says it's broken Hamas's military structure in northern Gaza. And a palace linked to Alexander the Great re-opens to visitors after 16 years.
item.itunes:subtitle: They need inspecting after part of a fuselage blew off during an Alaska Airlines flight
item.itunes:summary: The Federal Aviation Authority says Boeing 737 Max 9 jets must be inspected before flying again, after part of a plane's fuselage blew off during a US flight. The same Boeing models were grounded after deadly crashes in Ethiopia and Indonesia five years ago. Also: The Israeli army says it's broken Hamas's military structure in northern Gaza. And a palace linked to Alexander the Great re-opens to visitors after 16 years.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: The Happy Pod: Art student's lost work recovered thousands of kilometres away
item.description: Grace Hart's artwork was accidentally thrown away, only to end up in the Pakistani city of Lahore. Also: the jewellery store owners in Hawaii helping to restore precious items damaged in wildfires. And, the teenage darts player, 'Luke the Nuke', taking the sport to new audiences.
item.itunes:subtitle: Grace Hart's artwork was accidentally thrown away, only to end up in a Pakistani city
item.itunes:summary: Grace Hart's artwork was accidentally thrown away, only to end up in the Pakistani city of Lahore. Also: the jewellery store owners in Hawaii helping to restore precious items damaged in wildfires. And, the teenage darts player, 'Luke the Nuke', taking the sport to new audiences.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Biden launches blistering attack on Trump
item.description: The president accuses him of using language reminiscent of Adolf Hitler's Nazi Party, in his first election campaign speech of 2024. Also: Residents of the Russian border city of Belgorod are being moved to safety because of the persistent threat of Ukrainian attacks, and the Nigerian film that's winning big audiences and breaking a box office record.
item.itunes:subtitle: The president says he is a threat to US democracy
item.itunes:summary: The president accuses him of using language reminiscent of Adolf Hitler's Nazi Party, in his first election campaign speech of 2024. Also: Residents of the Russian border city of Belgorod are being moved to safety because of the persistent threat of Ukrainian attacks, and the Nigerian film that's winning big audiences and breaking a box office record.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Israel outlines post-war plans for Gaza
item.description: The Israeli defence minister, Yoav Gallant proposes a post-war plan for Gaza as UN aid agencies say their efforts to deliver aid in the region are being hindered by security risks and checkpoint delays. Also: Opinions divide in South Africa over the release from prison of the Paralympic champion Oscar Pistorius after serving eight and half years for killing his girlfriend. New images of Neptune and Uranus reveal they are not the colours we thought they were, and could Artificial Intelligence serve as your virtual therapist?
item.itunes:subtitle: Israel's defence minister has outlined proposals for governing Gaza once the war is over
item.itunes:summary: The Israeli defence minister, Yoav Gallant proposes a post-war plan for Gaza as UN aid agencies say their efforts to deliver aid in the region are being hindered by security risks and checkpoint delays. Also: Opinions divide in South Africa over the release from prison of the Paralympic champion Oscar Pistorius after serving eight and half years for killing his girlfriend. New images of Neptune and Uranus reveal they are not the colours we thought they were, and could Artificial Intelligence serve as your virtual therapist?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: North Korea 'provided Russia with missiles for Ukraine war'
item.description: The White House says newly declassified intelligence shows Russian forces used one such missile just last week. Also: Islamic State claims responsibility for twin bomb explosions that left 84 dead in Iran, and Elvis Presley is set to be brought back to life virtually as part of a new immersive concert experience in London.
item.itunes:subtitle: The White House says the information comes from newly declassified intelligence
item.itunes:summary: The White House says newly declassified intelligence shows Russian forces used one such missile just last week. Also: Islamic State claims responsibility for twin bomb explosions that left 84 dead in Iran, and Elvis Presley is set to be brought back to life virtually as part of a new immersive concert experience in London.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Funeral held for senior Hamas leader
item.description: Mourners gather in Lebanon after Saleh al-Arouri's assassination. Also: documents that name people connected to the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein have been released, and how a 13-year-old became the first person to defeat Tetris.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mourners gather in Lebanon after Saleh al-Arouri's assassination
item.itunes:summary: Mourners gather in Lebanon after Saleh al-Arouri's assassination. Also: documents that name people connected to the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein have been released, and how a 13-year-old became the first person to defeat Tetris.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Iran vows a harsh response after scores killed in blasts near general's tomb
item.description: There were two explosions near the tomb of the Iranian general Qasem Soleimani, who was killed in 2020 by a US drone. Also: Ukraine and Russia in "biggest prisoner swap" so far; Francoise Bornet - the woman in the famous Paris kiss photo dies aged 93.
item.itunes:subtitle: Many others were injured by the explosions in the Iranian city of Kerman
item.itunes:summary: There were two explosions near the tomb of the Iranian general Qasem Soleimani, who was killed in 2020 by a US drone. Also: Ukraine and Russia in "biggest prisoner swap" so far; Francoise Bornet - the woman in the famous Paris kiss photo dies aged 93.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Iran blasts: At least 73 killed
item.description: Hundreds of people were walking near the tomb of Iranian general Qasem Soleimani on the fourth anniversary of his assassination by the US. Also: Tensions rise in Lebanon following the killing of a deputy leader of Hamas, and why humans may be more attuned to the emotions of chickens than was ever thought.
item.itunes:subtitle: More than 170 are thought to be injured, after explosions hit a commemorative procession
item.itunes:summary: Hundreds of people were walking near the tomb of Iranian general Qasem Soleimani on the fourth anniversary of his assassination by the US. Also: Tensions rise in Lebanon following the killing of a deputy leader of Hamas, and why humans may be more attuned to the emotions of chickens than was ever thought.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Hamas deputy leader killed in Beirut blast
item.description: Saleh al-Arouri is the most senior Hamas figure killed since the Israel-Gaza war began in October. Also: Claudine Gay resigns as Harvard president, and a Chinese teenager is alive after US "cyber-kidnapping".
item.itunes:subtitle: Lebanon's PM has accused Israel of trying "to drag Lebanon into confrontation"
item.itunes:summary: Saleh al-Arouri is the most senior Hamas figure killed since the Israel-Gaza war began in October. Also: Claudine Gay resigns as Harvard president, and a Chinese teenager is alive after US "cyber-kidnapping".
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: All 379 passengers escape Japan Airlines fire after collision
item.description: Five people died on the other coastguard plane at Tokyo's Haneda Airport which was preparing to deliver aid to areas hit by Monday's earthquake. Also: Fury in Somalia as Ethiopia strikes a port access deal which effectively recognises breakaway Somaliland, and the sixteen year old World Championship darts sensation everyone is talking about in the UK.
item.itunes:subtitle: Five people died on the other plane at Tokyo's Haneda Airport
item.itunes:summary: Five people died on the other coastguard plane at Tokyo's Haneda Airport which was preparing to deliver aid to areas hit by Monday's earthquake. Also: Fury in Somalia as Ethiopia strikes a port access deal which effectively recognises breakaway Somaliland, and the sixteen year old World Championship darts sensation everyone is talking about in the UK.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Israel Supreme Court strikes down judicial reforms
item.description: The controversial plans triggered nationwide protests in Israel last year against Benjamin Netanyahu's government. Also: thousands in shelters overnight after Japan earthquake, and fancy owning a cuckoo clock museum?
item.itunes:subtitle: Critics say reforms would have undermined the country's democracy
item.itunes:summary: The controversial plans triggered nationwide protests in Israel last year against Benjamin Netanyahu's government. Also: thousands in shelters overnight after Japan earthquake, and fancy owning a cuckoo clock museum?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Thousands flee after powerful earthquake in Japan
item.description: The seven-point-six magnitude tremor brought down buildings and triggered a tsunami alert. Also; a celebrated Nobel Laureate is jailed in Bangladesh and, why there are new copyright rules for Mickey Mouse.
item.itunes:subtitle: The seven-point-six magnitude tremor brought down buildings and triggered a tsunami alert
item.itunes:summary: The seven-point-six magnitude tremor brought down buildings and triggered a tsunami alert. Also; a celebrated Nobel Laureate is jailed in Bangladesh and, why there are new copyright rules for Mickey Mouse.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Israeli military is making adjustments to its deployment in Gaza
item.description: IDF says some reserve units will be withdrawn from Gaza Strip. Also: Queen of Denmark announces abdication live on TV, and celebrations around the world to mark 2024.
item.itunes:subtitle: Meanwhile UN warns there is a risk of famine in Gaza without immediate food supplies
item.itunes:summary: IDF says some reserve units will be withdrawn from Gaza Strip. Also: Queen of Denmark announces abdication live on TV, and celebrations around the world to mark 2024.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine launches retaliatory attacks on Russia
item.description: It's one of the biggest waves of air strikes since Russia started the war, with the main target being Belgorod in the southwest. Also: Protests in the capital of South Darfur following a deadly bombing blamed on the Sudanese Armed Forces, and could a British Army officer have become the world's fastest woman to complete a solo South Pole ski expedition?
item.itunes:subtitle: At least eighteen people are killed and dozens wounded
item.itunes:summary: It's one of the biggest waves of air strikes since Russia started the war, with the main target being Belgorod in the southwest. Also: Protests in the capital of South Darfur following a deadly bombing blamed on the Sudanese Armed Forces, and could a British Army officer have become the world's fastest woman to complete a solo South Pole ski expedition?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: The Happy Pod: Mobile coverage reaches remote Norwegian town
item.description: Our weekly collection of the happiest stories in the world. This week, how a settlement in Norway is taking a unique approach to mobile phone etiquette, after getting signal for the first time. Also: the man who composes music on TikTok to tell short stories. And we look ahead at what's to come in the worlds of sport and music in 2024.
item.itunes:subtitle: The happiest stories in the world - our weekly collection
item.itunes:summary: Our weekly collection of the happiest stories in the world. This week, how a settlement in Norway is taking a unique approach to mobile phone etiquette, after getting signal for the first time. Also: the man who composes music on TikTok to tell short stories. And we look ahead at what's to come in the worlds of sport and music in 2024.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Massive Russian attacks on Ukraine kills dozens
item.description: The US President Joe Biden says the stakes of the war extend far beyond Ukraine, affecting the entirety of NATO and European security. Also: The authorities in the northern Ethiopian region of Tigray are warning it's at risk of a catastrophic famine, comparable to the one in the nineteen eighties, and what's in store for space exploration in 2024 and beyond?
item.itunes:subtitle: The largest aerial assault since the war began wreaks huge material damage
item.itunes:summary: The US President Joe Biden says the stakes of the war extend far beyond Ukraine, affecting the entirety of NATO and European security. Also: The authorities in the northern Ethiopian region of Tigray are warning it's at risk of a catastrophic famine, comparable to the one in the nineteen eighties, and what's in store for space exploration in 2024 and beyond?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Russia strikes Ukraine with huge air attack
item.description: Kyiv says 158 drones and missiles were fired targeting cities across the country. Also: A peace initiative develops in Cairo as the Israelis continue strikes on Gaza, and why lovers of luxury in Switzerland may soon have to say farewell to foie gras.
item.itunes:subtitle: Kyiv says 158 drones and missiles were fired targeting cities across the country
item.itunes:summary: Kyiv says 158 drones and missiles were fired targeting cities across the country. Also: A peace initiative develops in Cairo as the Israelis continue strikes on Gaza, and why lovers of luxury in Switzerland may soon have to say farewell to foie gras.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Venezuela orders military exercises as dispute with Guyana escalates
item.description: Tensions have risen since Venezuela renewed a claim to the the oil-rich Essequibo region, which for decades has been part of Guyana. Also: Congolese church leaders say they've found numerous cases of irregularities during the recent elections, and why 2023 was a bumper year for discoveries of new species around the world.
item.itunes:subtitle: The action is in response to Britain sending a warship to support Guyana
item.itunes:summary: Tensions have risen since Venezuela renewed a claim to the the oil-rich Essequibo region, which for decades has been part of Guyana. Also: Congolese church leaders say they've found numerous cases of irregularities during the recent elections, and why 2023 was a bumper year for discoveries of new species around the world.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: China tells nationals in part of northern Myanmar to leave
item.description: Beijing warns of escalating risk to its citizens as the conflict between the Burmese military and rebel groups intensifies. Also: Rights groups say the Indian government is continuing to target journalists by putting spyware on their phones, and we look at an attempt to break the Guinness World Record for the longest sing-a-thon.
item.itunes:subtitle: Beijing warns of escalating risk to its citizens as conflict intensifies
item.itunes:summary: Beijing warns of escalating risk to its citizens as the conflict between the Burmese military and rebel groups intensifies. Also: Rights groups say the Indian government is continuing to target journalists by putting spyware on their phones, and we look at an attempt to break the Guinness World Record for the longest sing-a-thon.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Maersk to resume sailings through Red Sea
item.description: The Danish shipping giant has scheduled several dozen container vessels following the deployment of a US-led naval alliance to safeguard international trade. Also: A high level US delegation is in Mexico to discuss the migration crisis, and we hear from the man behind the book Around The World In 80 Games.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Danish shipping giant has scheduled several dozen container vessels
item.itunes:summary: The Danish shipping giant has scheduled several dozen container vessels following the deployment of a US-led naval alliance to safeguard international trade. Also: A high level US delegation is in Mexico to discuss the migration crisis, and we hear from the man behind the book Around The World In 80 Games.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Israel expands its ground offensive in Gaza
item.description: Israel claims to have carried out strikes on at least 200 Hamas targets in 24 hours as the military expands its offensive. Also: dozens of barnacle-encrusted packages of cocaine wash up on beaches in Australia, and the impact of book bans on school children across the US.
item.itunes:subtitle: Israel claims to have carried out strikes on at least 200 Hamas targets in 24 hours
item.itunes:summary: Israel claims to have carried out strikes on at least 200 Hamas targets in 24 hours as the military expands its offensive. Also: dozens of barnacle-encrusted packages of cocaine wash up on beaches in Australia, and the impact of book bans on school children across the US.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Israel warns war in Gaza will continue for months
item.description: IDF is reportedly extending ground operations to central Gaza. Also: Daihatsu pauses car production over safety scandal, and what experiences will A.I. bring us in 2024?
item.itunes:subtitle: IDF is reportedly extending ground operations to central Gaza
item.itunes:summary: IDF is reportedly extending ground operations to central Gaza. Also: Daihatsu pauses car production over safety scandal, and what experiences will A.I. bring us in 2024?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukrainian strike on Russian warship
item.description: Russia has confirmed damage to its warship in the Black Sea. Also: thousands of migrants are en route from southern Mexico to the US border, and the first black referee in 15 years takes to the English Premier League football field.
item.itunes:subtitle: Russia has confirmed damage to its warship in the Black Sea
item.itunes:summary: Russia has confirmed damage to its warship in the Black Sea. Also: thousands of migrants are en route from southern Mexico to the US border, and the first black referee in 15 years takes to the English Premier League football field.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Happy News Review 2023
item.description: Our annual review of the happiest stories in the world. We look back on the successful rescue mission from a dangling cable car in Pakistan. Also: the children who survived forty days lost in the Colombian jungle. And a round-up of our favourite animal stories from around the world.
item.itunes:subtitle: The happiest stories in the world - our annual review
item.itunes:summary: Our annual review of the happiest stories in the world. We look back on the successful rescue mission from a dangling cable car in Pakistan. Also: the children who survived forty days lost in the Colombian jungle. And a round-up of our favourite animal stories from around the world.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Pope Francis appeals for peace in Gaza during Christmas Eve mass
item.description: Pope Francis said Jesus' message of peace is being drowned out by what he called the "futile logic of war". Also: Serbia protestors try to storm Belgrade City Hall, and scientists develop unique ways of collecting information about smells -- to preserve them for future generations.
item.itunes:subtitle: Israel has vowed to continue fighting in Gaza
item.itunes:summary: Pope Francis said Jesus' message of peace is being drowned out by what he called the "futile logic of war". Also: Serbia protestors try to storm Belgrade City Hall, and scientists develop unique ways of collecting information about smells -- to preserve them for future generations.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Yemen's warring parties commit to ceasefire steps
item.description: A UN envoy Hans Grundberg says Yemenis were watching and waiting for peace. Also: Israel says it holds hundreds of Hamas members, and two babies in two days for mum with double womb.
item.itunes:subtitle: The announcement follows meetings in Saudi Arabia and Oman
item.itunes:summary: A UN envoy Hans Grundberg says Yemenis were watching and waiting for peace. Also: Israel says it holds hundreds of Hamas members, and two babies in two days for mum with double womb.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: The Happy Pod: Cooking for togetherness
item.description: Our weekly collection of the happiest stories in the world. This week, how cooking is bringing generations together in the Netherlands. Also: how polar bear pawprints can help conservation efforts. And an unexpected visitor found in a Christmas tree.
item.itunes:subtitle: The happiest stories in the world - our weekly collection
item.itunes:summary: Our weekly collection of the happiest stories in the world. This week, how cooking is bringing generations together in the Netherlands. Also: how polar bear pawprints can help conservation efforts. And an unexpected visitor found in a Christmas tree.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US Supreme Court declines to fast-track Donald Trump immunity case
item.description: Former President says constitutional rules protect him from charges of attempting to overturn the last election. The UN security council passes a resolution aiming to bring more humanitarian aid to Gaza; and why France grounded an aircraft carrying 300 passengers on its way to Nicaragua.
item.itunes:subtitle: Former President wants to avoid facing charges of trying to overturn the last election
item.itunes:summary: Former President says constitutional rules protect him from charges of attempting to overturn the last election. The UN security council passes a resolution aiming to bring more humanitarian aid to Gaza; and why France grounded an aircraft carrying 300 passengers on its way to Nicaragua.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Prague university gunman linked to double murder a week earlier
item.description: It is the worst mass shooting in Europe since the 2015 terror attacks in Paris. Also: China announces new restrictions for online video games, and Spain's Christmas lottery 'El Gordo' dishes out millions of dollars
item.itunes:subtitle: Police say the gunman killed himself after opening fire on students and staff
item.itunes:summary: It is the worst mass shooting in Europe since the 2015 terror attacks in Paris. Also: China announces new restrictions for online video games, and Spain's Christmas lottery 'El Gordo' dishes out millions of dollars
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Gaza facing famine warns the UN
item.description: It found the entire population of two-point-two million people was suffering acute shortages. Also: Fourteen people are killed in a mass shooting at a university in the Czech capital, Prague. The gunman, a student, is also dead. And, the ABBA show that's giving hundreds of millions of dollars to London's economy.
item.itunes:subtitle: It found the entire population was suffering acute shortages
item.itunes:summary: It found the entire population of two-point-two million people was suffering acute shortages. Also: Fourteen people are killed in a mass shooting at a university in the Czech capital, Prague. The gunman, a student, is also dead. And, the ABBA show that's giving hundreds of millions of dollars to London's economy.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Plans for revamped European Super League announced
item.description: A court rules that clubs are allowed to join. An attempt to set up a European Super League collapsed two years ago. Also: Mounting insecurity in Sudan's Gezira state has led two leading aid agencies to halt operations, and the Ukrainian sports star who has moved from the tennis court to the battlefield.
item.itunes:subtitle: A court rules that clubs are allowed to join
item.itunes:summary: A court rules that clubs are allowed to join. An attempt to set up a European Super League collapsed two years ago. Also: Mounting insecurity in Sudan's Gezira state has led two leading aid agencies to halt operations, and the Ukrainian sports star who has moved from the tennis court to the battlefield.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: UN Gaza ceasefire vote delayed until Thursday
item.description: The Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu reiterates his commitment to continuing the offensive until Hamas is destroyed, as the number of people reported dead by Hamas passes twenty thousand. Also: Washington releases a close associate of the Venezuelan president in exchange for prisoners held by Caracas, and we hear about the Nigerian film that's making waves and is tipped to be nominated for an Oscar.
item.itunes:subtitle: The US says the world must put pressure on Hamas, not just Israel
item.itunes:summary: The Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu reiterates his commitment to continuing the offensive until Hamas is destroyed, as the number of people reported dead by Hamas passes twenty thousand. Also: Washington releases a close associate of the Venezuelan president in exchange for prisoners held by Caracas, and we hear about the Nigerian film that's making waves and is tipped to be nominated for an Oscar.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trump to appeal to US Supreme Court
item.description: It's after a Colorado court decision that he's ineligible to run in the state's primary contest because of his actions ahead of the January 6 riot. Also: Talks are continuing in Egypt over a possible pause in the fighting in Gaza, and the 8-year-old girl who beat a chess master 30 years her senior.
item.itunes:subtitle: It's after a Colorado court decision that he's ineligible to run in the state's primary
item.itunes:summary: It's after a Colorado court decision that he's ineligible to run in the state's primary contest because of his actions ahead of the January 6 riot. Also: Talks are continuing in Egypt over a possible pause in the fighting in Gaza, and the 8-year-old girl who beat a chess master 30 years her senior.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Crucial UN Gaza vote delayed again
item.description: Washington has become increasingly isolated in its staunch support for Israel's military campaign. Also: Sudan's army admits losing control of the central city of Wad Madani in a battle that's caused a quarter of a million people to flee, and we hear about festive drinks to get you into the Christmas spirit.
item.itunes:subtitle: Efforts continue to agree a text that won't be vetoed by the US
item.itunes:summary: Washington has become increasingly isolated in its staunch support for Israel's military campaign. item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Hundreds of thousands flee Sudan safe haven
item.description: The city of Wad Madani in al Jazira state had been home to those escaping the civil war. Also: we hear from one of the Thai hostages released by Hamas about his time in captivity, and Iceland experiences a spectacular volcanic eruption near the capital, Reykjavik.
item.itunes:subtitle: The city of Wad Madani had been home to those escaping the civil war
item.itunes:summary: The city of Wad Madani in al Jazira state had been home to those escaping the civil war. Also: we hear from one of the Thai hostages released by Hamas about his time in captivity, and Iceland experiences a spectacular volcanic eruption near the capital, Reykjavik.

Also: how a fascination with electricity inspired a Congolese woman to create a robotic medical tool. And the cyclist who took to the Olympic track after fleeing Afghanistan.

item.title: Special Edition - Artificial Intelligence - who cares?
item.description: What is AI? What can it do and what are its current limitations? A tool for good - or should we be worried? Will we lose our jobs? Are we ready to be cared for by machines? Our Tech Editor, Zoe Kleinman, and a panel of international experts explore AI's impact on healthcare, the environment, the law and the arts in a special edition recorded at Science Gallery London.

item.title: The Happy Pod: Saved from skin cancer
item.description:
Our weekly collection of the happiest stories in the world. This week, thanks for the eagle eyed doctor in Australia who spotted a serious medical problem on a TV interview and issued a very timely warning.  Praise in Colombia for the big sister who kept her little siblings alive in the jungle after their plane crashed. And the Mongolian women re-invigorating an old art-form for the twenty-first century.

Presented by Jackie Leonard. Music produced by Iona Hampson.

And the Mongolian women re-invigorating an old art-form for the twenty-first century.

Presented by Jackie Leonard. Music produced by Iona Hampson.

item.title: The Happy Pod: Rescue mission in Sudan
item.description: Around 300 children and babies rescued from an orphanage in the Sudanese capital, Khartoum. Also: We hear from one of the researchers helping a paralysed man to walk again, and why some people in Japan are relearning how to smile.

Presented by Andrew Peach. Music produced by Iona Hampson.

item.title: The Happy Podcast
item.description: Our new weekly collection of the happiest stories in the world along with the sounds that bring joy to our listeners. Presented by Andrew Peach. Music produced by Iona Hampson.

item.title: Special episode: Abortion rights around the world
item.description:
In June, the US Supreme Court overruled Roe v Wade and ended the constitutional right to abortion in America. In a special episode, we investigate the changing dynamic of abortion rights globally in countries like Colombia, China and Ireland. We'll also be examining the restrictions still faced by women in Africa and places like Malta and El Salvador.

Audio for this episode was updated on 4 July 2022, due to a factual error in an earlier version.
item.itunes:subtitle: We investigate the changing dynamic of abortion rights globally
item.itunes:summary:
In June, the US Supreme Court overruled Roe v Wade and ended the constitutional right to abortion in America. In a special episode, we investigate the changing dynamic of abortion rights globally in countries like Colombia, China and Ireland. We'll also be examining the restrictions still faced by women in Africa and places like Malta and El Salvador.

Audio for this episode was updated on 4 July 2022, due to a factual error in an earlier version.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Young voices special
item.description:
Is the nuclear threat real? What does Putin want? Who is winning the war in Ukraine? We took questions on the invasion from young people around the world and looked for answers from BBC correspondents.

Jackie Leonard speaks to Martin Forster, a senior child psychologist with the healthcare company, Kry, in Sweden. Listeners' questions are tackled by Vitaliy Shevchenko, Paul Adams, Theo Leggett, Lyse Doucet and Mark Lowen.
item.itunes:subtitle: We took questions on Ukraine from young people around the world
item.itunes:summary:
Is the nuclear threat real? What does Putin want? Who is winning the war in Ukraine? We took questions on the invasion from young people around the world and looked for answers from BBC correspondents.

Jackie Leonard speaks to Martin Forster, a senior child psychologist with the healthcare company, Kry, in Sweden. Listeners' questions are tackled by Vitaliy Shevchenko, Paul Adams, Theo Leggett, Lyse Doucet and Mark Lowen.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Special: Global News Ukrainecast part 2
item.description:
A month since the Russian invasion of Ukraine, we are collaborating with Ukrainecast again. We answer more of your questions.

Jackie Leonard, presenter of the Global News Podcast, alongside Gabriel Gatehouse and Vitaliy Shevchenko from Ukrainecast, guide us through questions about civilian life in the country, military tactics, and the international response to the invasion.

BBC chief international correspondent, Lyse Doucet, joins us from Kyiv to talk through what is happening on the ground there, and BBC security correspondent Frank Gardner, tells us the latest on the physical and information war.

This episode was made by Chris Flynn. The studio director was Ash Taylor. The assistant editor was Sam Bonham.
item.itunes:subtitle: We answer more of your questions about Ukraine
item.itunes:summary:

item.title: Russia-Ukraine: On the brink of war?
item.description: Our experts in Moscow, Kyiv and London answer your questions about the crisis.
item.itunes:subtitle: US President Biden warns Russia might invade Ukraine in February
item.itunes:summary: Our experts in Moscow, Kyiv and London answer your questions about the crisis.

item.title: Omicron versus the world: Your questions answered
item.description: As the Omicron variant spreads around the world and cases surge, BBC correspondents tell us how Covid-19 is impacting our lives, our businesses and our economies.
item.itunes:subtitle: The facts, the science, the politics, the economics and the myths
item.itunes:summary: As the Omicron variant spreads around the world and cases surge, BBC correspondents tell us how Covid-19 is impacting our lives, our businesses and our economies.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Afghanistan Special: Your Questions Answered
item.description:
BBC correspondents answer your questions about the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan. We ask how did the Taliban overthrow the Afghan government so quickly? What now for human rights, the economy and international relations?

Photo:People on board an evacuation flight out of Kabul airport, August 21, 2021 Credit:MoD/PA Wire
item.itunes:subtitle: BBC correspondents answer your questions about the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan

item.title: Global News Brexitcast
item.description: We team up with the award-winning Brexitcast team to bring you a special update on what Britain leaving the EU means for you. You’ve sent us questions from around the world and Jackie Leonard puts them to the experts from the podcast that’s all about Brexit. There’s also cake, phew. Spread the word! #GlobalNewsPod #Brexitcast Find the Brexitcast podcast here: http://www.bbc.co.uk/brexitcast
